pr_title: Add basic template for Secret Manager

timeline.author: meltsufin

timeline.bodyText:
I know it's a private method, but maybe even make it public?
Also for naming consistency: getSecretByteString?
timeline.author: meltsufin

timeline.bodyText:
Why do we need to expose it?
It's a bean in the application context anyway.
timeline.author: meltsufin

timeline.bodyText: Why not just have two overloaded methods: one with String and one with byte[]?
timeline.author: meltsufin

timeline.bodyText: You can get rid of this method if instead you rely on the two possible types: String and byte[].
timeline.author: meltsufin

timeline.bodyText: Typically we would create an interface as well called SecretManagerOperations.
timeline.author: meltsufin

timeline.bodyText: "Creates a new secret or a new version of existing secret"?
timeline.author: elefeint
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,89 @@ +/* + * Copyright 2017-2020 the original author or authors. + * + * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); + * you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. + * You may obtain a copy of the License at + * + * https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 + * + * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software + * distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, + * WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. + * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and + * limitations under the License. + */ + +package org.springframework.cloud.gcp.secretmanager; + +import com.google.protobuf.ByteString; + +/** + * Describes supported operations that one can perform on the Secret Manager API. + * + * @author Daniel Zou + * @since 1.3 + */ +public interface SecretManagerOperations { + + /** + * Creates a new secret using the provided {@code secretId} and creates a new version of + * the secret with the provided {@code payload}. + * + *

+ * If there is already a secret saved in SecretManager with the specified + * {@code secretId}, then it simply creates a new version under the secret with the secret + * {@code payload}. + * + * @param secretId the secret ID of the secret to create. + * @param payload the secret payload string. + */ + void createSecret(String secretId, String payload); + + /** + * Creates a new secret using the provided {@code secretId} and creates a new version of + * the secret with the provided {@code payload}.

timeline.bodyText: I wonder if setSecret is more precise, since the secret could be created or updated.
timeline.author: elefeint
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,89 @@ +/* + * Copyright 2017-2020 the original author or authors. + * + * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); + * you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. + * You may obtain a copy of the License at + * + * https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 + * + * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software + * distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, + * WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. + * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and + * limitations under the License. + */ + +package org.springframework.cloud.gcp.secretmanager; + +import com.google.protobuf.ByteString; + +/** + * Describes supported operations that one can perform on the Secret Manager API. + * + * @author Daniel Zou + * @since 1.3 + */ +public interface SecretManagerOperations { + + /** + * Creates a new secret using the provided {@code secretId} and creates a new version of + * the secret with the provided {@code payload}. + * + *

+ * If there is already a secret saved in SecretManager with the specified + * {@code secretId}, then it simply creates a new version under the secret with the secret + * {@code payload}. + * + * @param secretId the secret ID of the secret to create. + * @param payload the secret payload string. + */ + void createSecret(String secretId, String payload);

replies.bodyText: Ah, so in Secret Manager previous versions of secrets are never deleted; i.e. the Secret is like a container/parent, and then you create SecretVersions under the Secret. I think "create" would be correct, but not sure if there may be better choices for what is being created; like do you feel createSecretVersion may be more clear?
replies.author: dzou

replies.bodyText:
I think it's okay to leave it as is.
I thought about createSecretVersion but that takes focus off "secret" and onto "version", which is also not ideal.
replies.author: elefeint

replies.bodyText: Sounds good, will leave as is.
replies.author: dzou

timeline.bodyText: Does it make sense to just ask for getSecretString(String secretId) without specifying a version and getting back latest label by default? It feels like the most common usecase.
timeline.author: elefeint
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,89 @@ +/* + * Copyright 2017-2020 the original author or authors. + * + * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); + * you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. + * You may obtain a copy of the License at + * + * https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 + * + * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software + * distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, + * WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. + * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and + * limitations under the License. + */ + +package org.springframework.cloud.gcp.secretmanager; + +import com.google.protobuf.ByteString; + +/** + * Describes supported operations that one can perform on the Secret Manager API. + * + * @author Daniel Zou + * @since 1.3 + */ +public interface SecretManagerOperations { + + /** + * Creates a new secret using the provided {@code secretId} and creates a new version of + * the secret with the provided {@code payload}. + * + *

+ * If there is already a secret saved in SecretManager with the specified + * {@code secretId}, then it simply creates a new version under the secret with the secret + * {@code payload}. + * + * @param secretId the secret ID of the secret to create. + * @param payload the secret payload string. + */ + void createSecret(String secretId, String payload); + + /** + * Creates a new secret using the provided {@code secretId} and creates a new version of + * the secret with the provided {@code payload}. + * + *

+ * If there is already a secret saved in SecretManager with the specified + * {@code secretId}, then it simply creates a new version under the secret with the secret + * {@code payload}. + * + * @param secretId the secret ID of the secret to create. + * @param payload the secret payload as a byte array. + */ + void createSecret(String secretId, byte[] payload); + + /** + * Gets the secret payload of the specified {@code secretId} at version + * {@code versionName}. + * + * @param secretId unique identifier of your secret in Secret Manager. + * @param versionName which version of the secret to load. The version can be a version + * number as a string (e.g. "5") or an alias (e.g. "latest"). + * @return The secret payload as String + */ + String getSecretString(String secretId, String versionName);

replies.bodyText:
I added an overloaded method which omits versionName to return the latest.
According to a secret manager dev defulting to accessing the latest version may not be a "production best practice" so I think we ought to keep a method that accepts versions. #2168 (comment)
replies.author: dzou

timeline.bodyText: since we know whether a secret is new or existing, would it make sense to return a boolean flag, an enum or a version number indicating the result?
timeline.author: elefeint

replies.bodyText: I prefer void just to keep it simple for now; but definitely open to implementing this if users request for it in the future.
replies.author: dzou

timeline.bodyText:
This is not a large amount of logic, but it is repeated between the different overloaded versions of this method.
I think I'd call createSecret(String, byte[]) right away and not do any version determination in this method.
timeline.author: elefeint

timeline.bodyText: You can remove the intermediate build() calls -- proto builders usually take ether a final object or its builder.
timeline.author: elefeint

timeline.bodyText:
This can be a lot of secrets.
Can getSecret() be used instead to retrieve the specific secret?
timeline.author: elefeint

replies.bodyText: Done! The getSecret approach is now being used; requires a try/catch style.
replies.author: dzou

timeline.bodyText: Could it be useful as a public method?
timeline.author: meltsufin
